reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s percentile-based anchoring/normalization (best feasible = 99.99th percentile, extinction=0, cutoffs at 0.5/0.9) and argues this can manufacture “fussiness” when the upper tail is extreme. This is moderately central because the paper’s formal ‘mostly-great’/‘eutopia’ thresholds and some later quantitative comparisons depend on that scaling; if the scaling were badly distorting, parts of the argument about how common mostly-great futures are would weaken. However, it is not fully central: much of the paper’s case for ‘no easy eutopia’ is qualitative (many independent moral failure modes; multiplicative fragility; broad moral disagreement), and the authors explicitly note the threshold is not magical and could be varied. Strength is moderate-to-low because the critique shows a real sensitivity/measurement-risk but does not demonstrate that the paper’s main conclusion is an artifact rather than a robust claim across reasonable alternative anchors; the paper could reply that they intentionally define ‘best feasible’ via a high percentile to capture opportunity cost relative to the best realistically attainable, and that tail-heaviness is itself part of why targets are narrow on many views. Correctness is high: percentile anchoring can be tail-sensitive and can compress most outcomes below 0.5 when the upper tail is very large; the ‘tautological’ phrasing is somewhat overstated but points to a genuine methodological vulnerability. The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Anchoring value to extreme tail outcomes inflates apparent fragility
